title: Fetch data: select()
notes:
- By default, Supabase projects return a maximum of 1,000 rows. This setting can be changed in your project's [API settings](/dashboard/project/_/settings/api). It's recommended that you keep it low to limit the payload size of accidental or malicious requests. You can use `range()` queries to paginate through your data.
- `select()` can be combined with [Filters](/docs/reference/javascript/using-filters)
- `select()` can be combined with [Modifiers](/docs/reference/javascript/using-modifiers)
- `apikey` is a reserved keyword if you're using the [Supabase Platform](/docs/guides/platform) and [should be avoided as a column name](https://github.com/supabase/supabase/issues/5465).

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Harry'),
  (2, 'Frodo'),
  (3, 'Katniss');
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

```sql
INSERT INTO
```

examples.name: Query referenced tables
examples.description: If your database has foreign key relationships, you can query related tables too.
examples.code:
```js
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('orchestral_sections')
  .select(`
    name,
    instruments (
      name
    )
  `)
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  orchestral_sections (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references orchestral_sections,
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  orchestral_sections (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 2, 'flute'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Query referenced tables with spaces in their names
examples.description: If your table name contains spaces, you must use double quotes in the `select` statement to reference the table.
examples.code:
```js
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('orchestral sections')
  .select(`
    name,
    "musical instruments" (
      name
    )
  `)
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  "orchestral sections" (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  "musical instruments" (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references "orchestral sections",
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  "orchestral sections" (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  "musical instruments" (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 2, 'flute'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

log.message: Starting test: Query referenced tables with spaces in their names
Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Query referenced tables through a join table
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('users')
  .select(`
    name,
    teams (
      name
    )
  `)
  ```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  users (
    id int8 primary key,
    name text
  );
CREATE TABLE
  teams (
    id int8 primary key,
    name text
  );
-- join table
CREATE TABLE
  users_teams (
    user_id int8 not null references users,
    team_id int8 not null references teams,
    -- both foreign keys must be part of a composite primary key
    primary key (user_id, team_id)
  );

INSERT INTO
  users (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Kiran'),
  (2, 'Evan');
INSERT INTO
  teams (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Green'),
  (2, 'Blue');
INSERT INTO
  users_teams (user_id, team_id)
VALUES
  (1, 1),
  (1, 2),
  (2, 2);
```

examples.description:
If you're in a situation where your tables are **NOT** directly
related, but instead are joined by a _join table_, you can still use
the `select()` method to query the related data. The join table needs
to have the foreign keys as part of its composite primary key.

log.message: Starting test: Query referenced tables through a join table
Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Query the same referenced table multiple times
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('messages')
  .select(`
    content,
    from:sender_id(name),
    to:receiver_id(name)
  `)

// To infer types, use the name of the table (in this case `users`) and
// the name of the foreign key constraint.
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('messages')
  .select(`
    content,
    from:users!messages_sender_id_fkey(name),
    to:users!messages_receiver_id_fkey(name)
  `)
```

data.sql:
```sql
 CREATE TABLE
 users (id int8 primary key, name text);

 CREATE TABLE
   messages (
     sender_id int8 not null references users,
     receiver_id int8 not null references users,
     content text
   );

 INSERT INTO
   users (id, name)
 VALUES
   (1, 'Kiran'),
   (2, 'Evan');

 INSERT INTO
   messages (sender_id, receiver_id, content)
 VALUES
   (1, 2, 'ðŸ‘‹');
 ```

examples.description:
If you need to query the same referenced table twice, use the name of the
joined column to identify which join to use. You can also give each
column an alias.

log.message: Starting test: Query the same referenced table multiple times
Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Query nested foreign tables through a join table
examples.code:
```ts
  const { data, error } = await supabase
    .from('games')
    .select(`
      game_id:id,
      away_team:teams!games_away_team_fkey (
        users (
          id,
          name
        )
      )
    `)
  ```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  users (
    id int8 primary key,
    name text
  );
CREATE TABLE
  teams (
    id int8 primary key,
    name text
  );
-- join table
CREATE TABLE
  users_teams (
    user_id int8 not null references users,
    team_id int8 not null references teams,

    primary key (user_id, team_id)
  );
CREATE TABLE
  games (
    id int8 primary key,
    home_team int8 not null references teams,
    away_team int8 not null references teams,
    name text
  );

insert into users (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Kiran'),
  (2, 'Evan');
INSERT INTO
  teams (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Green'),
  (2, 'Blue');
INSERT INTO
  users_teams (user_id, team_id)
VALUES
  (1, 1),
  (1, 2),
  (2, 2);
INSERT INTO
  games (id, home_team, away_team, name)
VALUES
  (1, 1, 2, 'Green vs Blue'),
  (2, 2, 1, 'Blue vs Green');
```

examples.description:
You can use the result of a joined table to gather data in
another foreign table. With multiple references to the same foreign
table you must specify the column on which to conduct the join.

log.message: Starting test: Query nested foreign tables through a join table
Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Filtering through referenced tables
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('instruments')
  .select('name, orchestral_sections(*)')
  .eq('orchestral_sections.name', 'percussion')
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  orchestral_sections (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references orchestral_sections,
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  orchestral_sections (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 2, 'flute'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

examples.description:
If the filter on a referenced table's column is not satisfied, the referenced
table returns `[]` or `null` but the parent table is not filtered out.
If you want to filter out the parent table rows, use the `!inner` hint

log.message: Starting test: Filtering through referenced tables

examples.name: Querying referenced table with count
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('orchestral_sections')
  .select(`*, instruments(count)`)
```
examples.description:
You can get the number of rows in a related table by using the
**count** property.

examples.name: Querying with count option
examples.code:
```ts
const { count, error } = await supabase
  .from('characters')
  .select('*', { count: 'exact', head: true })
```

```sql
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO

VALUES
```

examples.description:
You can get the number of rows by using the

examples.name: Querying JSON data
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('users')
  .select(`
    id, name,
    address->city
  `)
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  users (
    id int8 primary key,
    name text,
    address jsonb
  );

INSERT INTO
  users (id, name, address)
VALUES
  (1, 'Frodo', '{"city":"Hobbiton"}');
```

examples.description:
You can select and filter data inside of
[JSON](/docs/guides/database/json) columns. Postgres offers some
[operators](/docs/guides/database/json#query-the-jsonb-data) for
querying JSON data.

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Querying referenced table with inner join
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('instruments')
  .select('name, orchestral_sections!inner(name)')
  .eq('orchestral_sections.name', 'woodwinds')
  .limit(1)
```
examples.description:
If you don't want to return the referenced table contents, you can leave the parenthesis empty.
Like `.select('name, orchestral_sections!inner()')`.

log.message: Starting test: Querying referenced table with inner join
Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Switching schemas per query
examples.description:
In addition to setting the schema during initialization, you can also switch schemas on a per-query basis.
Make sure you've set up your [database privileges and API settings](/docs/guides/api/using-custom-schemas).

log.message: Starting test: Switching schemas per query


examples.description:
A bulk create operation is handled in a single transaction.
If any of the inserts fail, none of the rows are inserted.

title: Modify data: update()
notes: - `update()` should always be combined with [Filters](/docs/reference/javascript/using-filters) to target the item(s) you wish to update.

title: Upsert data: upsert()
notes: - Primary keys must be included in `values` to use upsert.

examples.name: Upsert your data
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('instruments')
  .upsert({ id: 1, name: 'piano' })
  .select()
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'harpsichord');
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Bulk Upsert your data
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('instruments')
  .upsert([
    { id: 1, name: 'piano' },
    { id: 2, name: 'harp' },
  ])
  .select()
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'harpsichord');
```

log.message: Starting test: Bulk Upsert your data
Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Upserting into tables with constraints
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('users')
  .upsert({ id: 42, handle: 'saoirse', display_name: 'Saoirse' }, { onConflict: 'handle' })
  .select()
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  users (
    id int8 generated by default as identity primary key,
    handle text not null unique,
    display_name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  users (id, handle, display_name)
VALUES
  (1, 'saoirse', null);
```

examples.description:
In the following query, `upsert()` implicitly uses the `id`
(primary key) column to determine conflicts. If there is no existing
row with the same `id`, `upsert()` inserts a new row, which
will fail in this case as there is already a row with `handle` `"saoirse"`.
Using the `onConflict` option, you can instruct `upsert()` to use
another column with a unique constraint to determine conflicts.

log.message: Starting test: Upserting into tables with constraints

title: Delete data: delete()
notes:
- `delete()` should always be combined with [filters](/docs/reference/javascript/using-filters) to target the item(s) you wish to delete.
- If you use `delete()` with filters and you have
  [RLS](/docs/learn/auth-deep-dive/auth-row-level-security) enabled, only
  rows visible through `SELECT` policies are deleted. Note that by default
  no rows are visible, so you need at least one `SELECT`/`ALL` policy that
  makes the rows visible.
- When using `delete().in()`, specify an array of values to target multiple rows with a single query. This is particularly useful for batch deleting entries that share common criteria, such as deleting users by their IDs. Ensure that the array you provide accurately represents all records you intend to delete to avoid unintended data removal.

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  countries (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  countries (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Mordor');
```

title: Postgres functions: rpc()
description:
You can call Postgres functions as _Remote Procedure Calls_, logic in your database that you can execute from anywhere.
Functions are useful when the logic rarely changesâ€”like for password resets and updates.

```sql
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION hello_world() RETURNS text LANGUAGE sql AS
'SELECT ''Hello world''';
```

To call Postgres functions on [Read Replicas](/docs/guides/platform/read-replicas), use the `get: true` option.

examples.name: Call a Postgres function without arguments

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION hello_world() RETURNS text LANGUAGE sql AS
'SELECT ''Hello world''';
```

log.message: Starting test: Call a Postgres function without arguments
Test passed - results match expected output

```sql
CREATE TABLE

INSERT INTO

VALUES

  (2, 'The Shire');

CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION list_stored_countries() RETURNS SETOF countries LANGUAGE sql AS
'SELECT * FROM countries';
```

title: Using Filters
description:
Filters allow you to only return rows that match certain conditions.

Filters can be used on `select()`, `update()`, `upsert()`, and `delete()` queries.

If a Postgres function returns a table response, you can also apply filters.

examples.name: Applying Filters
examples.description:
Filters must be applied after any of `select()`, `update()`, `upsert()`,
`delete()`, and `rpc()` and before
[modifiers](/docs/reference/javascript/using-modifiers).
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('instruments')
  .select('name, section_id')
  .eq('name', 'violin')    // Correct

const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('instruments')
  .eq('name', 'violin')    // Incorrect
  .select('name, section_id')
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  orchestral_sections (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references orchestral_sections,
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  orchestral_sections (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 2, 'flute'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Chaining
examples.description:
Filters can be chained together to produce advanced queries. For example,
to query cities with population between 1,000 and 10,000:

```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('cities')
  .select('name, country_id')
  .gte('population', 1000)
  .lt('population', 10000)
```
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('cities')
  .select('name, country_id')
  .gte('population', 1000)
  .lt('population', 10000)
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  cities (id int8 primary key, name text, country_id int8, population int8);

INSERT INTO
  cities (id, name, country_id, population)
VALUES
  (1, 'San Francisco', 1, 800000),
  (2, 'New York', 1, 8000000),
  (3, 'Paris', 2, 2000000),
  (4, 'Berlin', 3, 3500000),
  (5, 'Tokyo', 4, 9000000);
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: Conditional Chaining
examples.description:
Filters can be built up one step at a time and then executed. For example:

```ts
const filterByName = null
const filterPopLow = 1000
const filterPopHigh = 10000

let query = supabase
  .from('cities')
  .select('name, country_id')

if (filterByName)  { query = query.eq('name', filterByName) }
if (filterPopLow)  { query = query.gte('population', filterPopLow) }
if (filterPopHigh) { query = query.lt('population', filterPopHigh) }

const { data, error } = await query
```
examples.code:
```ts
const filterByName = null
const filterPopLow = 1000
const filterPopHigh = 10000

let query = supabase
  .from('cities')
  .select('name, country_id')

if (filterByName)  { query = query.eq('name', filterByName) }
if (filterPopLow)  { query = query.gte('population', filterPopLow) }
if (filterPopHigh) { query = query.lt('population', filterPopHigh) }

const { data, error } = await query
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  cities (
    id int8 primary key,
    name text,
    country_id int8,
    population int8
  );

INSERT INTO
  cities (id, name, country_id, population)
VALUES
  (1, 'Small Town', 1, 500),
  (2, 'Medium City', 1, 2500),
  (3, 'Big City', 1, 15000),
  (4, 'Village', 1, 800),
  (5, 'Growing Town', 1, 5500),
  (6, 'Tiny Village', 1, 200),
  (7, 'Mid Town', 1, 7500),
  (8, 'Large City', 1, 25000),
  (9, 'Small City', 1, 3200),
  (10, 'Rural Town', 1, 1200);
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

examples.name: With `select()`

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
```

title: textSearch()
notes: - For more information, see [Postgres full text search](/docs/guides/database/full-text-search).

data.sql:
```sql
create table texts (
  id      bigint
          primary key
          generated always as identity,
  content text
);

insert into texts (content) VALUES
    ('Four score and seven years ago'),
    ('The road goes ever on and on'),
    ('Green eggs and ham')
;
```

examples.name: Basic normalization
examples.description: Uses PostgreSQL's `plainto_tsquery` function.
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('quotes')
  .select('catchphrase')
  .textSearch('catchphrase', `'fat' & 'cat'`, {
    type: 'plain',
    config: 'english'
  })
```

data.sql:
```sql
create table quotes (
  id bigint
     primary key
     generated always as identity,
  catchphrase text
);

insert into quotes (catchphrase) values
    ('The fat cat sat on the mat'),
    ('A lazy dog sleeps all day'),
    ('Fat cats love to eat fish'),
    ('The quick brown fox jumps over the fence'),
    ('Fat and happy cat purrs loudly')
;
```

examples.name: Full normalization
examples.description: Uses PostgreSQL's `phraseto_tsquery` function.
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('quotes')
  .select('catchphrase')
  .textSearch('catchphrase', `'fat' & 'cat'`, {
    type: 'phrase',
    config: 'english'
  })
```

data.sql:
```sql
create table quotes (
  id bigint
     primary key
     generated always as identity,
  catchphrase text
);

insert into quotes (catchphrase) values
    ('The fat cat sat on the mat'),
    ('A lazy dog sleeps all day'),
    ('Fat cats love to eat fish'),
    ('The quick brown fox jumps over the fence'),
    ('Fat and happy cat purrs loudly')
;
```

examples.name: Websearch
examples.description:
Uses PostgreSQL's `websearch_to_tsquery` function.
This function will never raise syntax errors, which makes it possible to use raw user-supplied input for search, and can be used
with advanced operators.

- `unquoted text`: text not inside quote marks will be converted to terms separated by & operators, as if processed by plainto_tsquery.
- `"quoted text"`: text inside quote marks will be converted to terms separated by `<->` operators, as if processed by phraseto_tsquery.
- `OR`: the word â€œorâ€ will be converted to the | operator.
- `-`: a dash will be converted to the ! operator.
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('quotes')
  .select('catchphrase')
  .textSearch('catchphrase', `'fat or cat'`, {
    type: 'websearch',
    config: 'english'
  })
```

data.sql:
```sql
create table quotes (
  id bigint
     primary key
     generated always as identity,
  catchphrase text
);

insert into quotes (catchphrase) values
    ('The fat cat sat on the mat'),
    ('A lazy dog sleeps all day'),
    ('Fat cats love to eat fish'),
    ('The quick brown fox jumps over the fence'),
    ('Fat and happy cat purrs loudly')
;
```

examples.code:

```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('characters')
  .select('name')
  .match({ id: 2, name: 'Leia' })
```

```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

log.message: Test passed - results match expected output

title: not()
notes:
not() expects you to use the raw PostgREST syntax for the filter values.

```ts
.not('id', 'in', '(5,6,7)')  // Use `()` for `in` filter
.not('arraycol', 'cs', '{"a","b"}')  // Use `cs` for `contains()`, `{}` for array VALUES
```

examples.name: With `select()`
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('countries')
  .select()
  .not('name', 'is', null)
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  countries (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  countries (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'null'),
  (2, null);
```

title: or()
notes:
or() expects you to use the raw PostgREST syntax for the filter names and values.

```ts
.or('id.in.(5,6,7), arraycol.cs.{"a","b"}')  // Use `()` for `in` filter, `{}` for array values and `cs` for `contains()`.
.or('id.in.(5,6,7), arraycol.cd.{"a","b"}')  // Use `cd` for `containedBy()`
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

examples.name: Use `or` on referenced tables
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('orchestral_sections')
  .select(`
    name,
    instruments!inner (
      name
    )
  `)
  .or('section_id.eq.1,name.eq.guzheng', { referencedTable: 'instruments' })
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  orchestral_sections (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references orchestral_sections,
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  orchestral_sections (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 2, 'flute'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

title: filter()
notes:
filter() expects you to use the raw PostgREST syntax for the filter values.

```ts
.filter('id', 'in', '(5,6,7)')  // Use `()` for `in` filter
.filter('arraycol', 'cs', '{"a","b"}')  // Use `cs` for `contains()`, `{}` for array VALUES
```

title: Using Modifiers
description:
Filters work on the row levelâ€”they allow you to return rows that
only match certain conditions without changing the shape of the rows.
Modifiers are everything that don't fit that definitionâ€”allowing you to
change the format of the response (e.g., returning a CSV string).

Modifiers must be specified after filters. Some modifiers only apply for
queries that return rows (e.g., `select()` or `rpc()` on a function that
returns a table response).

examples.name: With `upsert()`
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('characters')
  .upsert({ id: 1, name: 'Han Solo' })
  .select()
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Han');
```

examples.name: With `select()`
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('characters')
  .select('id, name')
  .order('id', { ascending: false })
```

data.sql:
```sql

INSERT INTO

VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

examples.name: On a referenced table
examples.code:
```ts
  const { data, error } = await supabase
    .from('orchestral_sections')
    .select(`
      name,
      instruments (
        name
      )
    `)
    .order('name', { referencedTable: 'instruments', ascending: false })
  ```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  orchestral_sections (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references orchestral_sections,
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  orchestral_sections (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 1, 'harp'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

examples.description:
Ordering with `referencedTable` doesn't affect the ordering of the
parent table.

examples.name: Order parent table by a referenced table
examples.code:
```ts
  const { data, error } = await supabase
    .from('instruments')
    .select(`
      name,
      section:orchestral_sections (
        name
      )
    `)
    .order('section(name)', { ascending: true })
  ```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  orchestral_sections (id int8 primary key, name text);
CREATE TABLE
  instruments (
    id int8 primary key,
    section_id int8 not null references orchestral_sections,
    name text
  );

INSERT INTO
  orchestral_sections (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'strings'),
  (2, 'woodwinds');
INSERT INTO
  instruments (id, section_id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 2, 'flute'),
  (2, 1, 'violin');
```

examples.description:
Ordering with `referenced_table(col)` affects the ordering of the
parent table.

```sql
INSERT INTO

VALUES
```

examples.code:

```ts
  .from('orchestral_sections')
  .select(`
    name,
    instruments (
      name
    )
  `)
  .limit(1, { referencedTable: 'instruments' })
```

title: abortSignal()
notes: You can use this to set a timeout for the request.

examples.name: Aborting requests in-flight
examples.code:
```ts
const ac = new AbortController()
ac.abort()
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('very_big_table')
  .select()
  .abortSignal(ac.signal)
```
examples.description:
You can use an [`AbortController`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController) to abort requests.
Note that `status` and `statusText` don't mean anything for aborted requests as the request wasn't fulfilled.

examples.name: Set a timeout
examples.code:
```ts
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('very_big_table')
  .select()
  .abortSignal(AbortSignal.timeout(1000 /* ms */))
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
```

examples.description: By default, the data is returned in JSON format, but can also be returned as Comma Separated Values.

examples.name: Override type of object response
examples.response:
```
let x: typeof data // MyType | null
```

examples.name: Complete Override type of successful response
examples.code:
```ts
const { data } = await supabase
  .from('countries')
  .select()
  .overrideTypes<Array<MyType>, { merge: false }>()
```

examples.name: Complete Override type of object response
examples.code:
```ts
const { data } = await supabase
  .from('countries')
  .select()
  .maybeSingle()
  .overrideTypes<MyType, { merge: false }>()
```
examples.response:
```ts
let x: typeof data // MyType | null
```

examples.name: Partial Override type of successful response
examples.response:
```ts
let x: typeof data // Array<CountryRowProperties & { status: "A" | "B" }>
```

examples.name: Partial Override type of object response
examples.response:
```ts
let x: typeof data // CountryRowProperties & { status: "A" | "B" } | null
```

title: Using Explain
description:
For debugging slow queries, you can get the [Postgres `EXPLAIN` execution plan](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-explain.html) of a query
using the `explain()` method. This works on any query, even for `rpc()` or writes.

Explain is not enabled by default as it can reveal sensitive information about your database.
It's best to only enable this for testing environments but if you wish to enable it for production you can provide additional protection by using a `pre-request` function.

Follow the [Performance Debugging Guide](/docs/guides/database/debugging-performance) to enable the functionality on your project.

examples.name: Get the execution plan

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

examples.response:

examples.description: By default, the data is returned in TEXT format, but can also be returned as JSON by using the `format` parameter.

examples.name: Get the execution plan with analyze and verbose

data.sql:
```sql
CREATE TABLE
  characters (id int8 primary key, name text);

INSERT INTO
  characters (id, name)
VALUES
  (1, 'Luke'),
  (2, 'Leia'),
  (3, 'Han');
```

examples.response:
```

  ->  Limit  (cost=0.00..18.33 rows=1000 width=40) (actual time=0.005..0.006 rows=3 loops=1)
```
